• A tiny javascript framework built on top of jQuery.
  • RESTful Evented JavaScript.
  • A way of allowing you to respond to specific URLS.
  • A way of creating single page applications that still respond to the back button

• A route can be thought of as an http request. It contains a verb, a path and a callback
  • A route can be defined directy using the route() function or by using one of the verb shortcuts: get(), post() put(), delete()

//Define a route using the built in get wrapper
this.get('#/', function(context) {
  context.log('Ho Ho Ho'!)
});


//Define a route using the route method
this.route('get', '#/', function(context) {
  context.log('Ho Ho Ho!');
});

• There are four verbs available to the developer: get, post, put & delete
  • These behave like their http namesakes
  • Three of the four available routes (put, post, delete) are only triggered on form submission.
